pages.raw_output: <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 81, 193, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 100, 767, 116]]<|/det|> UNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE INTERNATIONAL EXAMINATIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 116, 678, 131]]<|/det|> International General Certificate of Secondary Education <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 171, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 425, 258]]<|/det|>

<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 767, 91]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE student is measuring the capacity of a drinks cup by three methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 880, 138]]<|/det|>
The capacity of a cup is the maximum volume of liquid that it will hold in normal use. The maximum level is marked on the cup, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 151, 734, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 336, 339, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[584, 336, 653, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 144, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 368, 240, 386]]<|/det|>
Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 382, 792, 403]]<|/det|>
In Method 1, the capacity \(V_{1}\) is determined from the mass of water in the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 181, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 414, 875, 448]]<|/det|>
The cup is filled to the marked level with water. It is then placed on the balance, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 460, 435, 479]]<|/det|>
Read and record its mass \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 490, 871, 510]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 522, 181, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 521, 875, 567]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the capacity \(V_{1}\), using your reading from **(a)**(i) and the equation \(V_{1} = \frac{m}{\rho}\), where \(\rho = 1.00 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 657, 875, 677]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 243, 88]]<|/det|>
## Method 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 85, 851, 107]]<|/det|>
In Method 2, the capacity \(V_{2}\) is measured directly from the volume of water in the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 881, 153]]<|/det|>
The cup is filled to the marked level and the water is tipped into a measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 165, 650, 560]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 578, 510, 597]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 703, 628]]<|/det|>
Read and record the volume \(V_{2}\) of water in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 638, 875, 658]]<|/det|>
<form>V_2 = ............................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 242, 91]]<|/det|>
Method 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 87, 828, 123]]<|/det|>
In Method 3, the capacity \(V_{3}\) is calculated by considering the cup as a cylinder, the average diameter of the cup and an approximate equation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 138, 688, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 508, 512, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 181, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 539, 769, 560]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.4, measure and record the diameter \(d_{1}\) of the top of the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 570, 875, 590]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d_{1} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 600, 181, 619]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 782, 621]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.4, measure and record the diameter \(d_{2}\) of the base of the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 632, 875, 653]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d_{2} =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 663, 183, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 662, 875, 698]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.4, measure and record the height \(h\) from the base to the marked level MAX.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 694, 875, 714]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h =\) .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 710, 875, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 740, 181, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 739, 875, 787]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) using your readings from **(c)(i)** and **(c)(ii)**, and the equation \(D = \frac{(d_1 + d_2)}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 904, 875, 923]]<|/det|>
<form>\(D =\) ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 771, 92]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE student is investigating methods of preventing loss of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 712, 123]]<|/det|>
The student is using two beakers labelled \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[44, 128, 890, 567]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 580, 509, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 732, 631]]<|/det|>
Beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) has a layer of insulation and beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) has a lid but no insulation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 644, 875, 678]]<|/det|>
The beakers contain hot water at the start of the experiment. The initial temperatures are as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 144, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 691, 875, 724]]<|/det|>
Read, and record in the first row of Table 2.1, the temperatures of the water in beakers \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\) at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 704, 875, 722]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 737, 146, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 737, 875, 770]]<|/det|>
The temperatures of the hot water after 30s, 60s, 90s, 120s, 150s and 180s are shown in Table 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 782, 719, 801]]<|/det|>
Complete the column headings and enter the values of \(t\) in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 798, 875, 816]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

Justify your answer by referring to the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 469, 406, 488]]<|/det|> beaker ................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 500, 871, 518]]<|/det|> justification ....................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 578, 875, 597]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 146, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 609, 875, 642]]<|/det|> State one condition that should be controlled to ensure that the comparison between beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) and beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) is a fair one. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 686, 875, 704]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 821, 109]]<|/det|>
A student points out that the experiment does not test the effectiveness of insulation reducing thermal energy loss.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 875, 154]]<|/det|>
Suggest a change to this experiment which could be made so that the effect of insulation could be investigated. Explain why this change would help.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 873, 185]]<|/det|>
suggestion .................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 225, 873, 245]]<|/det|>
explanation .................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 92]]<|/det|> IGCSE students are investigating the current and potential difference in an electrical <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 376, 121]]<|/det|> The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 128, 828, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 505, 509, 524]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 146, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 875, 570]]<|/det|> The potential difference across part of the resistance wire, and the current in the circuit are to be measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 581, 875, 615]]<|/det|> On Fig. 3.1, use an appropriate circuit symbol to draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference between \(\mathbf{X}\) and \(\mathbf{Y}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 611, 875, 630]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 641, 146, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 641, 875, 660]]<|/det|> The crocodile clip is connected in turn to the resistance wire at points \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\), \(\mathbf{C}\), \(\mathbf{D}\), \(\mathbf{E}\) and \(\mathbf{F}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 875, 705]]<|/det|> The potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) are measured for each position and recorded in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 718, 517, 737]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 749, 756, 940]]<|/det|>
positionV/VI/A
A1.30.20
B1.20.35
C1.10.46
D0.90.74
E0.80.87
F0.61.13

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 183, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 594, 92]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (y-axis) against \(I / \text{A}\) (x-axis).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 106, 769, 452]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 454, 876, 473]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 553, 181, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 552, 875, 588]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(M\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 700, 875, 720]]<|/det|>
<form>M = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 730, 180, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 730, 819, 749]]<|/det|>
The gradient \(M\) is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 761, 875, 797]]<|/det|>
Write down the resistance \(R\) to a number of significant figures suitable for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 807, 875, 826]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 698, 92]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE class is investigating the reflection of light by a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 531, 122]]<|/det|>
One student's ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 141, 205, 159]]<|/det|>
ray-trace sheet

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 152, 887, 768]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 785, 509, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 816, 146, 834]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 816, 771, 835]]<|/det|>
In the first part of the experiment, a plane mirror is to be placed on line \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 847, 181, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 846, 875, 881]]<|/det|>
Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\), towards the top of the page. Label the other end of this normal \(\mathbf{L}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 887, 181, 906]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 887, 858, 906]]<|/det|>
Two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) are placed on line \(\mathbf{LN}\). Label suitable positions for \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 905, 875, 923]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 808, 107]]<|/det|> The mirror is placed on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) are viewed from direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 876, 155]]<|/det|> Two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) are placed so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) , and the pin \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) all appear exactly in line with \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 181, 184]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 663, 185]]<|/det|> Draw a line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) and reaching \(\mathbf{AB}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 190, 180, 208]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 189, 875, 223]]<|/det|> Measure the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal NL. Record this value in Table 4.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 207, 875, 225]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 146, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 235, 875, 271]]<|/det|> The mirror is then moved to line \(\mathbf{EF}\) and pins \(\mathsf{P}_{5}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{6}\) are placed in line with the new images. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 282, 761, 301]]<|/det|> Repeat steps **(b)**(i) and **(b)**(ii) using the new mirror line and pin positions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 282, 875, 301]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 319, 515, 337]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 351, 717, 448]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha /\textsuperscript{o}\)\(\theta /\textsuperscript{o}\)
mirror on CD20
mirror on EF30

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 705, 92]]<|/det|>
Two IGCSE students are investigating the melting of ice cubes in water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 871, 138]]<|/det|>
They are dropping ice cubes into hot water at different temperatures and measuring the time taken for the cubes to melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 480, 168]]<|/det|>
This is a page from one student's notebook.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 183, 695, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 146, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 470, 875, 504]]<|/det|>
In the space below, draw a suitable table. Enter the readings in such a way that it is easier to see a pattern from them.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 501, 875, 519]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
